advert.description: <br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT (1984)</strong></font><br><blockquote>"Kaypro, it runs" ! <br><br> "Kaypro, the computer which can be carried away" <br><br> "Elected Transportable Computer of the year"</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> AN ADVERTISING FOR THE BM JR</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> ADVERT #1</strong></font><br><blockquote>As it's often the case with these promotional pictures, the whole scene sounds fake and so... unreal.</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT (JANUARY 1982)</strong></font><br><blockquote>"At 68 years old, taunt Rose discovered that she was an exceptionally gifted child"</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> U.S. ADVERT (1980)</strong></font><br><blockquote>In september 1980, over 200,000 Model 1 were sold, more than 50,000 units per month since the computer was launched.</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> U.K. AD. (NOV. 1986)</strong></font><br><blockquote>Same offer and same sale prices as in December 1985</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH BROCHURE #1</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Thanks to <b>Jacques Sorro</b></p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> BROCHURE COVER</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> DISPLAY SIZE ARGUMENT CLOSE-UP</strong></font><br><blockquote>The Osborne 1 was the major competitor of the KAYCOMP in the portable computers field.</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> U.S. ADVERT #2 (1982)</strong></font><br><blockquote>As the first advert campaing was not a good idea, NEC of America replaced it with this one... which was not better</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> ISAAC ASIMOV AD #2</strong></font><br><blockquote>Advert said:<br><br><font color="#666666"> Our word processing system changed Isaac Asimov's mind about writing...<br> <b>"I may never use a typewriter again!"</b> Isaac likes the time he saves using SuperSCRIPSIT, our newest word processing program...<font></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>>  ACORN AD #2</strong></font><br><blockquote>Advert said:<br><font color="#666666"> This attractive package inherits the traditions of the famous Model B BBC microcomputer which is used by children in almost every school in the United Kingdom as well as colleges, hospitals, laboratories, factories, offices, banks and shops. </font><p class="petitgris">Courtesy of <b>8bs.com</b></p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> NEWBURRY BROCHURE #3</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Courtesy of <b>www.oldcomputers.freeserve.co.uk </b></p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> US BROCHURE (RECTO)</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Thanks to Chris Collman for this picture</p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> USER MANUAL'S COVER</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> VICTOR AD #2 (1982)</strong></font><br><blockquote>In this advert, the Victor 9000 features was compared with those of four competitor computers: IBM PC, Xerox 820, Apple III and TRS-80 Model II. <br><br> Victor features was definitely higher than all of the desktop computers of the time, including the IBM PC. </blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT #3</strong></font><br><blockquote>"With a cool teacher, computers is a child game" <br><br> "Alice, the Basic teacher"</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> 1978 BROCHURE #17</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> UK ADVERT</strong></font><br><blockquote>From Personal Computer World, October 1983<br><br> Here are some answers:<br><font color="#666666"> "The BBC Microcomputers are the limousines of home computers. The graphics are probably the best' of any machine in this class. You are paying for Ii smart machine which would not disgrace the home of a professional."<br> <i>Video World., Feb. '83.</i><br><br> "Its design has given the BBC Micro an unrivalled potential for business, educational and serious home applications. It has been equipped to function as the heart of a system which can be expanded 10 suit its owner's need?"<br> <i>Which Micro & Software Review, Feb. '81</i><br><br> "The most attractive and exciting feature of the BBC Microcomputer is its enormous potential for expansion which will allow a higly expansive system to be built-up?"<br> <i>Which Micro, June '82.</i><br><br> "They (the graphics) are tremendously exciting, and they are one of the features that make this machine stand out head and shoulders above everything else that is available in the market place at this time"<br> <i>Educalional Computing, May '82</i><br><br> "It is expandable and has a powerful BASIC. It has superb sound and graphics, the software is readily available and the price is righ"<br> <i>BBC Micro owner from Hampshire.</i><br><br> "The basics are easy to follow. My wife has developed a program for teaching our daughter French vocabulary. Our daughter uses it mainly for games and simple programming"<br> <i>BBC Micro owner from Co. Durham.</i><br><br> "It is a very powerful computer, My husband has written his own data base. I have been writing programs and programming games. Even the children have written small programs."<br> <i>BBC Micro owner from Devon.</i><br><br> "No other computer can offer such ease of use when dealing with complex sound effects."<br> <i>Which Micro, June '82.</i><br><br> "It isn't often a journalist can sit down to write about a computer with the certain knowledge that he has never seen a nicer machine."<br> <i>Personal Computer World, Dec. '82</i> "It has got huge potential. Besides playing the games, the whole family are learning basic programming."<br> <i>A BBC Micro owner from Staffordshire.</i><br><br> "Everything possible seems to have been done to ensure that this is not a 'dead end' machine.."<br> <i>Personal Computer World, July '82.</i></font> </blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> PROMOTIONAL LEAFLET</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Thanks to Juan Antonio Maestre for this picture</p></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> 5500 ADVERT (JAN. 1981)</strong></font><br><blockquote>This is a french advert for the ISTC 5500 published in january 1981. Its is exactly the same advert used for the model 5000, apart some modification in the description (disk drive capacity). Even the picture is still the same, with a "5" added with a pen, by hand !!!</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> PROMO PIC #6</strong></font><br><blockquote>Thanks to its optional modem, the TO-7/70 could be connected to the Teletel communication network. This skilled photograph is browsing the Liberation (popular french newspaper) site. <br><br> But there are still no cables shown here ! How the whole system is running ?!</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> SWEDISH ADVERT</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> TAPE RECORDER ADVERT</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Courtesy of <b>8bs.com</b></p></blockquote>

computer.coprocessor: game selection, skill level (1, 2 or 3), power/reset
computer.description:
After both Atari and Magnavox released their first pong systems (Odyssey 100, Odyssey 200, Pong) in 1975, Magnavox continued with the Odyssey 300 in 1976, which was one of the first system to use a single game chip containing the major circuitry of a PONG system. This system was Magnavox' answer to Coleco Telstar, the first game to use the GI AY-3-8500 chip.
From the manual: "Odyssey 300 literally turns your TV screen into a challenging electronic playground, and it attaches to any size or brand... black and white or color. Odyssey 300 features games of Hockey, Tennis and Smash, and as an extra challenge has switchable skill levels of Novice, Intermediate and Expert which automatically adjusts the player size, speed of the ball and deflection of the ball."
computer.name: Odyssey 300
